3FC0992A1DBA4432AB58E83B88F09360.description: identify, analyze and assess the collaborative processes used by individuals whose careers involve the development and production of literary texts [such as the collaborative relationships of author, illustrator, editor and publisher and of playwright, actor, producer and director]

EE8079373BC74F12AFBAAB050AAF03C1.description: understand and appreciate the function of teamwork tools, assess how to work effectively and collaboratively as a team to accomplish a task, understand the role of conflict in a group to reach solutions, and manage and resolve conflict when appropriate

F9759216AB264CB2A1019EECCD46C8DE.description: use and appreciate various means to facilitate completion of group projects

00DF9EDFD909458ABBCF0152D80BD0BB.description: analyze and explain the interplay among the roles adopted by group members; and lead or support, when appropriate, motivating a group for high performance

968273BB4F494ADAA289887A7FE68EC3.description: develop and use criteria to monitor and assess group processes [such as division of labour and time management]

356DE6BC76104FEA88BD8133BCE24367.description: ensure that a team's purpose and objectives are clear

4BFA439A53FA4B8F83D96F9F170E7A3F.description: reflect on and describe strategies used to negotiate, coordinate and cooperate with others; select appropriate strategies for negotiating, coordinating and cooperating with others; monitor selected strategies; and modify selected strategies as needed to accomplish group goals

983481944E564ED19D3F46DCE6AB5FFD.description: set appropriate personal goals for participation in a group; respect, be open to, and be supportive of the thoughts, opinions and contributions of others in a group; and share personal knowledge, expertise and perspectives with others, as appropriate

A4F24A5258D34F4FBF3E42D0143A3437.description: Cooperate with others, and contribute to group processes

49876B5281134416903B928CAA5E5F67.description: describe various means by which language and image are used appropriately to honour people and to celebrate events, and explain how these means of using language and image help to build community [for example, heritage day; wall of honour or photography exhibit; and naming ceremonies, religious ceremonies and prayers of First Nations and Aboriginal peoples]

E3650EC6FCB8482483B4EEBBAFBF55C4.description: use language and image to honour own and others' accomplishments [for example, celebrate together when classmates have accomplished a particular task or produced, published or presented a particular text; or celebrate the completion of a portfolio with family and friends by holding a "portfolio launch"]

96F2CC7FDF3547F4B5B6F33D77D3FC5B.description: explain how a text creator's underlying assumptions influence his or her ideas, opinions and selection of supporting details

A0497C9368FB4FE585DA7BA58F9D49F5.description: explain how selected works of literature and other print and nonprint texts convey, shape and, at times, challenge individual and group values and behaviours

D9EC00A30EC845EA836C0CDCC7716E77.description: appreciate diversity of thought and expression, select and monitor appropriate strategies for appreciating diversity, and modify selected strategies as needed

ADEBDFDDC7F249C495D84604AB984DFC.description: Appreciate diversity of expression, opinion and perspective

554D4106B91041C68F3416D2F940F40F.description: explain, when applicable, how a specific text demonstrates that the parameters of public tolerance regarding the use of language and image have changed over time

A219BBEF863B4C8789CB3FC1B632EDC7.description: accept, offer and appreciate the value of constructive criticism [for example, use writing to respond to constructive criticism, and accept and provide feedback in a constructive and considerate manner]

C2DA813D760742DC9A37CC3012B5C171.description: analyze behavioural expectations of a communication situation, explain how verbal and nonverbal communication contributes to the inclusion or exclusion of individuals involved in a communication situation, and use verbal and nonverbal communication that is inclusive of other individuals [for example, use empathetic listening skills when working in groups, and be aware of body language]

3A7AFF2B05084B1B9D7725B5F9187D63.description: analyze and describe positive or negative portrayals of characters in literature and persons in life, and be sensitive to the feelings of others

3124D97B877548D1BD0BE500A33B8993.description: explain how language and images are used in literature and other texts to convey respectful and considerate, or disrespectful and inconsiderate, perspectives and attitudes [for example, parody or journalistic bias in print, visual and multimedia texts]

54E359B4FD254C94A34267EB16863DB5.description: monitor own use of verbal and nonverbal communication in order to convey respect and consideration, as appropriate [for example, use euphemism and body language appropriately and sensitively]

BA3C73463A4A4D049C944D8943F8F46C.description: Use language and image to show respect and consideration

F8119C3DD79F428FA286BC2CEF74EB86.description: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view and represent to respect, support and collaborate with others.

BE48BFBF84C443ADBE509BEEB0603105.description: assess strengths and areas of need [for example, develop a checklist of skills mastered and skills to be developed, and set goals for language growth]

233FD828A2AB497D94FBACB99B8A8BDE.description: pay particular attention to punctuation, spelling, grammar, usage and sentence construction when using unfamiliar vocabulary, complex syntax and sophisticated rhetorical devices

1ED62DF218CF46399DF86AAB89E817F4.description: assess and revise texts in progress to ensure the correct use of clauses and phrases, including verbal phrases (participle, gerund and infinitive), and to ensure the correct use of structural features [such as appositives and parallel structure]

D3A2A2D9E98D481A91D2F8D54FC59958.description: use unconventional punctuation, spelling and sentence structure for effect, when appropriate [for example, use nonstandard spelling to indicate dialect, and use sentence fragments for emphasis, when appropriate]

C46F4A1F93C54AAAB78BB1D50CC5854F.description: assess and revise texts in progress to ensure correct subject-verb agreement, correct pronoun case and appropriate consistency of verb tense

6013D7D24DD84520B70AEDE45EA7BE33.description: understand the importance of grammatical agreement; and assess and revise texts in progress to ensure correctness of grammatical agreement, including correct pronoun reference and pronoun-antecedent agreement, and correct use of modifiers and other parts of speech

AE420841466E4FA099303EF0689B9581.description: know and be able to apply spelling conventions consistently and independently

3BF838CEFC9442A4A6BBDFCA4E253A8F.description: know and be able to apply capitalization and punctuation conventions correctly, including end punctuation, commas, semicolons, colons, apostrophes, quotation marks, hyphens, dashes, ellipses, parentheses, underlining and italics

D618AA88B5464702886AF63CA613BEBE.description: use handbooks and other tools, including electronic tools, as resources to assist with text creation [for example, dictionaries, thesauri, spell checkers and handbooks]

E22932A03BB6405BA0D9994E1CA45A36.description: Edit text for matters of correctness

159C02CF6A50491A9D178AA00194A7AD.description: develop a repertoire of stylistic choices that contribute to personal voice

926B81748CFC4C60BEAB3CB54E018AE4.description: explain how stylistic techniques and rhetorical devices are used to create intended effects

C8F9CC2755594C3DB02440C2F42AC157.description: assess syntax for appropriateness and effectiveness, and revise sentence structures as needed to create intended effects

3640520833084AC4A1338AEC59C9F4D7.description: assess the appropriateness and effectiveness of diction, and revise word choice as needed to create intended effects

5426BBD4509B4BD08057C8E0CC449C85.description: reflect on personal vocabulary and repertoire of stylistic choices and on their effectiveness; and expand vocabulary and repertoire of stylistic choices

6C2CE635450F42469A5B971BE6106A45.description: Consider and address matters of choice

426A438CF7244A2895191153BE365A76.description: apply the concepts of unity and coherence to ensure the effective organization of oral, print, visual and multimedia texts

E23C008CBB3449A7A9A4137C74F9998E.description: assess the closing of a text in progress; and revise it as needed to ensure that it is related to purpose, that it establishes a sense of developed understanding and that it will have an appropriate effect on audience

CE8182E5A71D4573A57D5E703C800D8D.description: assess the organizational components of a text in progress, and revise them as needed to strengthen their effectiveness as units of thought or experience or to strengthen their contribution to other intended effects [such as emphasis or transition]

1342F06BCEFA483F9E22212D892C05C2.description: make revisions as needed to ensure that the beginning of a text in progress establishes purpose and engages audience [for example, the rhetorical question or anecdote used to begin a speech, or the establishing shot of a video]

9C92F953FC344ECAA099914905AE3172.description: assess the plausibility and appropriateness of literary interpretations and the precision, completeness and relevance of evidence when reviewing and revising critical/analytical responses to literature

E097D1E8CDA34325903257E08AF31459.description: assess reasoning for logic and evidence for consistency, completeness and relevance; and strengthen reasoning as needed by adding to, modifying or deleting details to provide significant evidence and make effective and convincing arguments [for example, work with a small group to use a revision strategy like Workshop Advice, where each person in the group provides one suggestion for a sentence change]

43A4977549CF46E894FAB0D069A686FB.description: review the accuracy, specificity, precision, vividness and relevance of details, events, images, facts or other data intended to support a controlling idea or to develop a unifying effect; and add to, modify or delete details, events, images, facts or other data as needed to provide complete and effective support or development

5A690DFAE23E4E328BF98CA431DBCBC0.description: assess the effectiveness of the controlling idea or desired unifying effect of a text in progress, and refine the controlling idea or desired unifying effect as appropriate to meet the intended purpose

1E27CB4E1553470D8A9C16F9A1E0EAAE.description: Enhance thought and understanding and support and detail

681F3B97FA0644ED8B74126BFA09465B.description: Improve thoughtfulness, effectiveness and correctness of communication

4BAA3A06200442D4BE9B20C62803EEB8.description: create rapport with an audience, by selecting from a repertoire of effective strategies [for example, use humour to open a presentation and set a positive tone with the audience]

F685D8368A0A459D846972EF323FBE61.description: develop and deliver oral, visual and multimedia presentations, using voice production factors [such as volume, tone and stress], nonverbal factors [such as gestures, posture, distance and eye contact] and visual production factors [such as colour and contrast] appropriate to purpose, audience and situation

ACE91B632A844DCB911AC8C6EA675BC0.description: adapt presentation strategies to suit changes in purpose, audience and situation [for example, use close physical proximity, eye contact and other body language strategies effectively to regain audience attention following an interruption]

A489DD7A47E64975A0F4C82B3C22640B.description: meet particular production, publication and display requirements for print texts [for example, adhere to a particular manuscript style when creating a research paper]; and explain requirements in light of purpose, audience and situation

61371A856DF044F6A79A23A1D852B3D2.description: Use production, publication and presentation strategies and technologies consistent with context

25BF5A5885D2454E80FAB5F7D39A4552.description: incorporate effective examples from personal experience, concepts and ideas from exploration, and findings from inquiry and research into created texts, when appropriate [for example, incorporate visual aids in a prepared speech and taped sound effects in a dramatization of a scene from a play]

2570B8AB7A1A4FEBAD366B7F326A9C1E.description: develop content consistent with form and appropriate to context [for example, link questions and answers when reporting the results of an interview]

9063E752106F49AA92835DF54412B6D9.description: develop appropriate, relevant and sufficient content to support a controlling idea or unifying effect [for example, relate supporting details, examples and illustrations to a controlling idea when creating a critical/analytical response to literature]

ED88DBCBA3D5407FBB4A3552F977A33D.description: develop supporting details, by using developmental aids appropriate to form and purpose [for example, use charts to collect and assemble details in creating character comparisons when developing a comparison and contrast essay, or use a think-aloud reading strategy to make notes from informational text when writing a summary]

0F8779A8F0D8459488B2263A1EA0CD6B.description: establish a focus for text creation, and communicate scope by framing an effective controlling idea or describing a strong unifying effect

B75547F2EE8D4DD9AAB5D91FACDA4AF6.description: recognize and assess personal variables [such as personal experience and prior knowledge] and contextual variables [such as availability of time and resources] that influence the selection of a topic, concept or idea; and address these variables to increase the likelihood of successful text creation

560DA965EB7A44788E4165A0121343B1.description: take ownership of text creation, by selecting or crafting a topic, concept or idea that is personally meaningful and engaging

D67CD4D2B70F4144A87269414682A0AB.description: depart from the conventions of oral, print, visual and multimedia texts, as appropriate to purpose, audience and situation [for example, employ the conventions of fiction when creating factual narrative to fulfill purpose and create audience effects]; and assess the impact on text creation

54C36C0C832D487B9DF8E90B591EBC7C.description: understand the concept of convention; and apply it to oral, print, visual and multimedia text forms when appropriate [for example, understand the common conventions of a modern play script; and include dialogue, stage directions, and directions for lighting and sound effects when creating a script, as appropriate]

3A80B6E0001E4668BBF23259C94BD0BF.description: select an effective medium appropriate to content and context; and explain the interplay of medium, context and content [for example, select a medium like television, and assess the interplay of medium, context and content by examining the role that investigative reporters play in reporting world events in a timely and interesting manner]

1372CEFA8FD64B058B48E5FA84FB1AEE.description: use a variety of complex structures consistent with form, content and purpose when creating texts; and explain reasons for choices [for example, use frames in a storyboard, including dialogue as appropriate to review organization, and explain why these complex structures are an effective way to create a video text]

39D0D34DC5B94F3E8BAA2D312FEF48DB.description: select a text form appropriate to the purpose for text creation and consistent with the content to be presented in the text [for example, select a photo essay to demonstrate a personal or critical/analytical response to poetry or other literature when the content to be presented is well suited to the creation of a visual text]

C0B22FBFD7054B37AC703BAAFE1CFA04.description: Consider and address form, structure and medium

8519BAC7CF574FC7AD83B186F1198543.description: assess whether or not the strategies used to deal with the expectations and constraints of a communication situation were effective [for example, distribute a formal evaluation form to the audience at the end of a meeting, to assess whether or not the strategy of providing time in small-group discussions resolved the issue of lack of time for all audience members to ask questions and express opinions]

1A9C1CD3E0EB4CC6B88D4572618599FB.description: analyze audience factors that affect text creation, and explain how consideration of audience factors has affected choices made while creating a text

40E13181BBD14AE89CDFEBC8AF300FD3.description: assess the results of text creation in terms of the intended purpose and whether or not the target audience was engaged [for example, assess the effectiveness of a job application letter in terms of whether or not the potential employer read the résumé]

285FAB2E502646828B617726072F0C0E.description: reflect on the purposes for text creation [for example, to inform, explain, persuade, entertain or inspire] and on own motives for selecting strategies to engage an audience [for example, to communicate information, promote action or build relationships]; and consider potential consequences of choices regarding text creation [for example, follow-up action may be required to clarify information, a position may need to be defended and opposing viewpoints addressed, and tone and style must be appropriate for intended audience]

5B5782C46721477491C50E0B25956350.description: Develop and present a variety of print and nonprint texts

8C09BA7770BF44E390FD2CB79EB35246.description: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view and represent to create oral, print, visual and multimedia texts, and enhance the clarity and artistry of communication.

654D03E0F0D54A87A2F903EA515C0D00.description: seek feedback from others and use own reflections to evaluate the entire inquiry or research process, strive for craftsmanship and accuracy, and take pride in efforts and accomplishments

4FF3EB04D5274AF68FB358E78F9D6A0B.description: review the appropriateness, accuracy and significance of findings, conclusions and generalizations drawn from gathered data and information; prepare a detailed record of references; determine how best to share the information; and determine next steps, if any

2F64BF25E643455E82F6291BF720B279.description: identify strategies to improve future inquiry or research, and monitor the effectiveness of these strategies

CEA69839841E47B8A16B8AE4EA12038F.description: reflect on and assess the effectiveness of strategies used to guide inquiry or research [such as the effective use of time and the division of labour when involved in group research]

8368E2D5937D4904A003722D525B81FC.description: Review inquiry or research process and findings

79788319BFD447399A14B11655525EF8.description: support generalizations and conclusions sufficiently with relevant and consistent detail

A36FED6F6B264191A517F0190DBF1ACF.description: draw conclusions that are appropriate to findings, reflect own understandings and are consistent with the identified topic, purpose and situation

45BE4DC9103E46628433B0AAE06413CB.description: form generalizations and synthesize new ideas by integrating new information with prior knowledge

3365B365B72347A2B0732946DFFA929A.description: identify and describe possible biases and vested interests of sources; and explain how underlying assumptions, biases, and positive or negative spin affect the credibility of sources

069C52D5633F4C758E59C302ABE2703F.description: assess the accuracy, completeness, currency and relevance of information selected from sources; and assess the appropriateness of the information for purpose

55FC3D3395434B5DA50041A994EC7116.description: assess information sources for appropriateness to purpose, audience and presentation form

35EFDD1067144D0D974BCEF4D5728826.description: reflect on and describe strategies to evaluate information sources for credibility and bias and for quality; and select, monitor and modify strategies as needed to evaluate sources and detect bias

6B11AE3D44484EF7B2F4579F28F69CA1.description: observe guidelines for Internet use [for example, keep passwords, telephone numbers and addresses confidential; visit appropriate sites; respect copyright; and observe rules for citing Internet sources, following correct procedures to avoid plagiarism]

C85868AF261342F9A6DD69A7229AB022.description: organize information logically [such as by question, by category, by chronology or by cause and effect]

C80E80D3CE7340CCB848B7BFA374A90B.description: record information accurately and completely; and document and reference sources, as appropriate [for example, document direct quotations, others' ideas and arguments, maps, charts, statistics, pictures and diagrams from books, magazines, bibliographies, newspapers, audiovisual materials, electronic sources, interviews and films to avoid plagiarism]

3E10BE8436E14EB1A706088FD4A91AF9.description: select information and other material appropriate to purpose from a variety of print and nonprint sources [for example, from museums, archives, government agencies, periodicals, microfiche, Internet, CD-ROMs, films, television and radio broadcasts, interviews, surveys, and print and online encyclopedias]

3046C4CB021C40159559EF7867F757CC.description: reflect on and describe strategies that may be used to select, record and organize information; select and monitor appropriate strategies; and modify selected strategies as needed

7CB17AD12C304705BA3B2B55031FFDD4.description: develop and draw from a repertoire of effective strategies and technologies for gathering, generating and recording information

0EE39CF1A1DE4B3EB638038A1E5FED39.description: identify and predict the usefulness of information sources intended to fill gaps between prior knowledge and required information [for example, whether or not a survey or interview will be useful]

5ABA5302586F4429955CE60E96BB85BB.description: assess the breadth and depth of prior knowledge, and refine questions to further satisfy information needs and to guide the collection of new information

09977E75BF2B4CB684E7DDEAFA3739B1.description: select from a repertoire of effective strategies to develop appropriate inquiry or research plans that will address the topic and satisfy contextual and presentation requirements [for example, questions within questions, inquiry charts, preliminary interviews, and consultations with the teacher and/or librarian]

A482AB33FBF844DBA2F1B30A79F016E7.description: reflect on and describe strategies for developing an inquiry or research plan that will foster understanding, select and monitor appropriate strategies, and modify strategies as needed to plan inquiry or research effectively [for example, use a research journal to keep and record reflections on the research process, clarify thinking, revisit initial perceptions and ask questions that lead to new research]

122EDFE4F9CC468EA2735F2D3C0838BF.description: Plan inquiry or research, and identify information needs and sources

E870FFB14886414D8B1F278618A7CE54.description: refine the purpose of inquiry or research by limiting or expanding the topic as appropriate

7EADD7AA098149629ECCA8DA00E2470C.description: describe the purpose of inquiry or research and the scope of the inquiry or research topic; identify the target audience; and identify the potential form for the presentation of inquiry or research findings, when applicable [such as a narrative, report, diary entry or biography]

567FEA3B2573490F9EB3B91A0B7F4A67.description: modify selected strategies as needed to refine the depth and breadth of inquiry or research and to identify the purpose, audience and form of presentation

78266754933142928A783AAA8F813255.description: Focus on purpose and presentation form

E2740481B77845209C5EFCA5DFE6C882.description: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view and represent to manage ideas and information.

B3B050523AD64A64B17DB95A51020D0E.description: appreciate the craft of the text creator and the shape and substance of literature and other texts

F65266F2693A42DA9B2D0D08E277EB83.description: use terminology appropriate to the forms studied for discussing and appreciating the effectiveness and artistry of a variety of text forms

D1922F9FF0344EADA7604D6EB62DDEC2.description: Appreciate the effectiveness and artistry of print and non-print texts

C811D8F2431244669A33C7C0EA28D89A.description: assess the significance of a text's theme or controlling idea, and the adequacy, relevance and effectiveness of its supporting details, examples or illustrations, and content in general

CED665E5052B45339CC514197B42A17D.description: analyze and assess images in print and nonprint texts in terms of created reality and appropriateness to purpose and audience

1A05DF03AF154817A9EAE6230BB1F8BB.description: analyze and assess character and characterization in terms of consistency of behaviour, motivation and plausibility, and in terms of contribution to theme [for example, determine the meanings suggested by a change in a character's behaviour or values]

314C3DE142384103AF5A9BD525D44B8F.description: analyze and assess settings and plots in terms of created reality and plausibility [for example, determine the authenticity of the setting of a work of historical fiction]

B234C740E11448DDA32E32AA45FB5248.description: assess the appropriateness of own and others' understandings and interpretations of works of literature and other texts, by referring to the works and texts for supporting or contradictory evidence

293FF7E2F9B543A2B8D83C7889679999.description: identify criteria to evaluate the effectiveness of texts, monitor the effectiveness of the criteria, and modify the criteria as needed [for example, use criteria to assess the adequacy, relevance and effectiveness of content and to assess the text creator's voice and style]

E678364A5853404E8C10DC4A0F6AFB1E.description: Evaluate the verisimilitude, appropriateness and significance of print and non-print texts

F96DC908DBC643348DD4D248078D0879.description: respond personally and critically to the ways in which cultural and societal influences are reflected in a variety of Canadian and international texts

E1C2E37A3592473394AE75527700621B.description: assess the choices and motives of characters and people portrayed in texts in light of the choices and motives of self and others

C4D99825AD98419EBFB1C3B91FEC2E58.description: form positions on issues that arise from text study; and assess the ideas, information, arguments, emotions, experiences, values and beliefs expressed in works of literature and other texts in light of issues that are personally meaningful and culturally significant

8C35495C678E435BA21CF2551E2D353A.description: identify and consider personal, moral, ethical and cultural perspectives when studying literature and other texts; and reflect on and monitor how perspectives change as a result of interpretation and discussion

5956F3D1D5C7448FBE6420EA8AC3E965.description: Connect self, text, culture and milieu

9DD489DF32F740C1B8344BD827309A4F.description: Respond to a variety of print and non-print texts

AADF5E459F47449681679D5DA28790BC.description: assess the use of persuasive techniques and their effects on audience [for example, assess the use of commercial endorsements and negative advertisement campaigns, which may convince or offend]

09C1DC6353504C34BA411B6801C13571.description: analyze the various elements of effective presentation, and assess the effects created [for example, colour to create symbolism or mood, and gestures to enhance clarity]

4F663DC83A464BE997EB8233A760A2D3.description: explain the contribution of motif and symbol to controlling idea and theme

82543CDBF40C4CF2AC5EB97C74155B05.description: assess the use of musical devices, figures of speech and sensory details to create effects in a variety of print and nonprint texts

407BE9C67B114AC8A740C5CE42F099A1.description: analyze the use of irony and satire to create effects in print and nonprint texts [for example, dramatic irony to create suspense, verbal irony to create humour, and satire to evoke response]

B043A36BD54F48F281C86311E82656C8.description: assess the contributions of textual elements and stylistic techniques to the creation of atmosphere, tone and voice

81C621A14C1F4D8E8AFB4AA021E5A929.description: assess the contributions of rhetorical devices and stylistic techniques to the clarity and coherence of print and nonprint texts, and assess the various means by which devices and techniques are used to emphasize aspects or portions of a text

ACFD93F94B69444F8B7CFCE897BC4CAE.description: Relate elements, devices and techniques to created effects

52AC3479D7174F4F8BCDE0A7422728E8.description: assess the medium of a presentation in terms of its appropriateness to purpose and content and its effect on audience [for example, the use of unamplified voice, printed handouts and computer generated slides]

DC78AF86E3C848E098879CBF6C410684.description: apply knowledge of organizational patterns and structural features to understand purpose and content, and assess the effectiveness of a text's organizational structure

B4EB53B9AEC34435A5AC431F3FDD99D2.description: assess the potential influence of various audience factors on a text creator's choice of form and medium

A4834BA6D657457890559D73DA5BDD43.description: analyze a variety of text forms, explain the relationships of form to purpose and content, and assess the effects of these relationships on audience

BA5F266CD3764E84A94F1E7C0930CA13.description: Relate form, structure and medium to purpose, audience and content

9DF31E0BBF09433886F66FAE398FEDED.description: Understand and appreciate textual forms, elements and techniques

4EF0E826F3B64136997B785A04498C0E.description: create and use own reference materials to aid understanding [for example, a personalized dictionary/glossary and a personalized World Wide Web/URL address list]

22E9F278B2A7401584CCEA13ED7A0981.description: use a variety of appropriate reference strategies and reference technologies to aid understanding [for example, formulating and refining questions, exploring works cited in other references, taking notes, and using library catalogues and Internet search engines]

27CBC75004FC47DEA725A63E265177ED.description: Use reference strategies and reference technologies

A5330145ADF248A8AA7A2599F3905EAC.description: classify the genre/form of new texts according to attributes of genres/forms previously studied

328AFE3FD9804BCF841904FEA47FD5BB.description: identify variations and departures from the conventional use of rhetorical devices, textual elements and structures in texts; and describe the purpose and effect of such variations and departures

337E882405C7493985F72C6B86DEBA7A.description: assess prior knowledge of contexts, content and text forms; and explain how it contributes to new understandings

6457F1B0B49A45A4BD092710B10186FA.description: reflect on and describe strategies used to engage prior knowledge as a means of assisting comprehension of new texts; and select, monitor and modify strategies as needed

3B26677990114131BC0D86A7E0795712.description: assess the relationship between the content of a presentation and the performance of the presenter, and explain how the quality of the performance affects the credibility and audience acceptance of the content and message

3E7E197217F644D4910B9028DB842C59.description: assess the contributions that visual and aural elements make to the meaning of texts

0BD63E466CBE43C0A8A231746BF06A83.description: assess the contributions of figurative language, symbol, imagery and allusion to the meaning and significance of texts; and appreciate the text creator's craft

626C9653F14D46DC82FC1B54452B2ADC.description: relate a text creator's tone and register to the moral and ethical stance explicitly or implicitly communicated by a text

54B907D6ED594FF3A070A4367E92E6DC.description: analyze the personality traits, roles, relationships, motivations, attitudes and values of characters developed/persons presented in literature and other texts; and explain how the use of archetypes can contribute to the development of other textual elements, such as theme

89F0D3CC7A3040458C41539A7622DFDB.description: assess the contributions of setting, plot, character and atmosphere to the development of theme when studying a narrative

62DBABFB187C43AABFD6F108959137E6.description: analyze the relationships among controlling ideas, supporting ideas and supporting details in a variety of texts

B815921D3C284E1DBE58243CD50BCBFB.description: use a variety of strategies to comprehend literature and other texts [for example, reading passages out loud, forming questions, making predictions, using context to determine the connotative meanings of words, using graphic organizers and making annotations], and develop strategies for close reading of literature in order to understand contextual elements [for example, understanding subtext]

51235350C2FD49839AABA9F48B660AB6.description: identify the impact that personal context - experience, prior knowledge - has on constructing meaning from a text

97A6D604AFAD4726BAEFB042F8C8FE4A.description: explain how understanding the interplay between text and context can influence an audience to appreciate a text from multiple perspectives [for example, an audience can appreciate how historical and societal forces present in the context in which a text is set can affect the style, diction and point of view chosen by the text creator]

505B843BCF7B47D8B6619304C186A7E2.description: analyze elements or causes present in the communication situation surrounding a text that contribute to the creation of the text [for example, whether a text creator is communicating as an individual or as a member of a particular group]

ECA99482AEE842BDB361267221FEE4E6.description: explain the text creator's purpose, including implicit purpose when applicable; describe whether or not the purpose was achieved [for example, describe an author's use of juxtaposition to develop a contradictory impression of a character]; and assess the suitability of a text to the target audience

E797C565946349A2BD5477A25C336165.description: Construct meaning from text and context

A5428B1E98944C518014AD0922158FBE.description: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view and represent to comprehend literature and other texts in oral, print, visual and multimedia forms, and respond personally, critically and creatively.

A2B9BDDFFB034985A904F75F08A92E90.description: identify and access learning sources and opportunities; assess, weigh and manage risk; and demonstrate a willingness to continuously learn and grow

3ECAFCB4D89A445986FC8D3BB2F45D17.description: set goals and draw from a repertoire of effective strategies for language growth in relation to aspirations for the future [such as post-secondary learning and potential careers]

1BD7942C68754ACCB1648C97C2F5BAE6.description: appraise own strengths and weaknesses as a language user and language learner; select appropriate strategies to increase strengths and address weaknesses; monitor the effectiveness of selected strategies; and modify selected strategies as needed to optimize growth [for example, assess growth in writing by using a writing portfolio and portfolio reflections]

796838E887C847F3B24E2B0EABE676C1.description: Set personal goals for language growth

D10255DBC44E4971A4C406E3FE078E1D.description: cultivate appreciation for a variety of genres, texts, text creators and texts in translation from other countries [for example, providing specific examples, choose a universal theme; create a list of works of literature, movies, songs, videos and art; and discuss why some works are timeless]

E1253C08846C453B89E13F2ABF4A2344.description: reflect on personal text preferences, identify influences that have contributed to the formation of these preferences, and select strategies that may be used to expand interests in texts and text creators [for example, complete and share reading inventories, and examine the role marketing plays in shaping popular culture]

25B1A6C3959C4BEDB2AA666E853AB5CF.description: analyze and evaluate how various topics and themes, text forms, text types and text creators influence own and others' understandings, attitudes and aspirations

D59D9132E641415AA43B0400459AEC9F.description: recognize and assess the strengths and limitations of various perspectives on a theme, issue or topic, and identify aspects for further consideration when exploring and responding to texts

AB1340BAF3A54118A1F10AACB21CA30A.description: select appropriate strategies to extend awareness and understanding of new perspectives, monitor their effectiveness, and modify them as needed [for example, record new understandings in a learning log; develop new group perspectives using a fish bowl organization]

D6CD7A6AA8A04082A2765974976E8EE7.description: experiment with a variety of strategies, activities and resources to explore ideas, observations, opinions, experiences and emotions [for example, stream-of-consciousness writing, free verse poetry, exploratory talk and improvisation]

DF41AB368ECC4977AB9AD39F16EC1113.description: explain how experiments with language, image and structure improve personal craft and increase effectiveness as a text creator [for example, use a writer's journal or idea folder on a computer to collect ideas, newspaper articles and first writing attempts; rework this information into stories, poems or articles; and share with teachers and peers to receive feedback]

D02646CA87794DD880BB82DDB2079953.description: Experiment with language, image and structure

436EC40763764679A80E627B4ECEA672.description: modify tentative interpretations and tentative positions by weighing and assessing the validity of own and others' ideas, observations and opinions; and identify areas for further inquiry or research

117B13E0ADEA47B19DF4528738BB3704.description: draw from a repertoire of effective strategies to form tentative understandings, interpretations and positions [for example, record initial thoughts, feelings and observations about a novel in a dialogue journal]

3D9B4FAA787045AEB539AC32BE6248C0.description: Form tentative understandings, interpretations and positions

776D588060C0477DA82AF978F599F641.description: Students will listen, speak, read, write, view and represent to explore thoughts, ideas, feelings and experiences.
